I think as a country we should focus on due process (not assuming any side 
is right or wrong) until all of the evidence is out. Both sides jump to 
conclusions. It becomes all about raw emotion and mob mentality, rather 
than being objective and just analyzing the facts. In any case before any 
of the facts are out, people are going to lean towards one side or the 
other in a biased way, letting their emotions pull them along instead of 
analyzing the facts. In this specific situation though, I don't even see 
any evidence that this case was motivated by race. The cop was being 
attacked and defended himself. I think the people who initially claimed 
that Michael Brown had his hands up, and then later changed their story, I 
think that brings questions to the table. My point is, even if there are 
cases where there's no evidence of racial motivation, the media turns it 
into a race issue, because race is a hot topic, and hot topic = more views. 
Some cases are sincerely racial in nature and the offender was motivated by 
race, some cases its police brutality (and whites have been the target of 
police brutality too, all across the nation), and other cases, its just a 
cop trying to defend himself. But because people are swayed by their 
emotions, right when the case comes out, before we even get all the facts, 
people are ready to jump to conclusions on both sides. Our system of law 
wasn't meant to be about a mob mentality, it's supposed to be due process 
and objectively looking at the facts, emotions put aside. That's the point 
I'm trying to make.﻿

the treatment of blacks and whites in Ferguson does not in and of itself 
implicate racism.  The question is whether said disparity is caused by a 
bias on the police's part, or by general behavioral differences between 
Whites and Blacks.  If for example you look up homicide statistics in the 
Bureau of Justice Statistics website, it will show that per capita 
Black-on-White homicides account for more than an order of magnitude higher 
than White-on-Black homicides.  The difference is so great, (approximately 
12:1), that in order for it to be in error, the means for collecting and 
accounting for the data would need to be so scandalously bad as to 
implicate the Department of Justice of racism.  I can't imagine the data 
having any value at this point.  But it has been consistent for over 20 
years.   http://www.bjs.gov/index.cfm?ty=pbdetail&iid=2221

assume that a difference in the reaction to said groups justifies a racial
